Rota—Baxter operators of zero weight on simple Jordan algebra of Clifford type

V. Gubarev

Abstract

It is proved that any Rota—Baxter operator of zero weight on Jordan algebra of a nondegenerate bilinear symmetric form is nilpotent of index less or equal three. We state exact value of nilpotency index on simple Jordan algebra of Clifford type over fields ℝℝ\mathbb{R}, ℂℂ\mathbb{C}, and ℤpsubscriptℤ𝑝\mathbb{Z}_{p}. For ℤpsubscriptℤ𝑝\mathbb{Z}_{p}, we essentially use the results from number theory concerned quadratic residues and Chevalley—Warning theorem.

Keywords: Rota—Baxter operator, Jordan algebra of Clifford type, quadratic residue, Chevalley—Warning theorem.

1 Introduction

In 1933, the physicist P. Jordan introduced in quantum mechanics a notion of Jordan algebra [12]. A Jordan algebra J𝐽J over a field F𝐹F of characteristic ≠2absent2\neq 2 is a commutative (nonassociative) algebra over F𝐹F satisfying the Jordan identity (x2​y)​x=x2​(y​x)superscript𝑥2𝑦𝑥superscript𝑥2𝑦𝑥(x^{2}y)x=x^{2}(yx).

Any associative algebra under the new product x∘y=12​(x​y+y​x)𝑥𝑦12𝑥𝑦𝑦𝑥x\circ y=\frac{1}{2}(xy+yx) is a Jordan algebra. For example, a matrix algebra under ∘\circ turns to be a simple Jordan algebra. Moreover, the set of self-adjoint matrices over ℝℝ\mathbb{R}, ℂℂ\mathbb{C}, or ℍℍ\mathbb{H} with the product ∘\circ is a Jordan algebra (of Hermitian type). The set of self-adjoint matrices of order three over the octonions under ∘\circ is a 27-dimensional simple Jordan algebra (of Albert type). Given a vector space V𝑉V with nondegenerate bilinear symmetric form f𝑓f, one can equip a space F⊕Vdirect-sum𝐹𝑉F\oplus V with a structure of simple Jordan algebra provided dim(V)≥2dimension𝑉2\dim(V)\geq 2 (Clifford type).

The first classification theorem for Jordan algebras was obtained by P. Jordan, J. von Neumann, and E. Wigner in 1934 [13]. In 1978–1983, E. Zelmanov was a leader of so called Russian revolution [14] in theory of Jordan algebras. In particular, he proved that any prime (including simple) Jordan algebra without absolute zero divisors is either of Hermitian, or Albert, or Clifford type [17].

Jordan algebras are deeply connected with Lie algebras and finite simple groups (Kantor—Köcher—Tits construction, The Freudenthal—Tits Magic Square) [11, 14].

Let us refer a reader to the excellent monographs on Jordan algebras [11, 14, 18] written by N. Jacobson, K. McKrimmon, and K.A. Zhevlakov et al.

The notions of Rota—Baxter operator and Rota—Baxter algebra were introduced by G. Baxter in 1960 [3] as a generalization of by part integration formula. Since 1960s, J.-C. Rota, P. Cartier, L. Guo, C. Bai and others studied combinatorial and algebraic properties of Rota—Baxter algebras (see details in a unique monograph on the subject written by L. Guo in 2012 [9]).

Also, the deep connection of Rota—Baxter algebras with Yang—Baxter equation, quantum field theory and Loday algebras was found [4, 15, 1, 7, 2, 8].

In 1935, C. Chevalley [5] and E. Warning [16] proved two very close theorems which are now gathered in one Chevalley—Warning theorem. This theorem states than over finite field any system of polynomial equations with sufficiently large number of variables has a solution. From that time, a lot of connections and applications of Chevalley—Warning theorem were found such that combinatorial Nullstellensatz, Erdös—Ginzburg—Ziv theorem etc. (see, e.g. [6]).

The goal of the current work is to investigate Rota—Baxter operators of zero weight on simple Jordan algebra of a nondegenerate bilinear form. At first, we prove that all such operators are nilpotent of index not greater than 3. At second, we are interested on the exact value of nilpotency index of Rota—Baxter operators of zero weight. It occurs that the nilpotency index of Rota—Baxter operators of zero weight on simple Jordan algebra of Clifford type depends on the dimension of algebra and the ground field. If the ground field is finite, we essentially use Chevalley—Warning theorem and its corollaries.

We are always mentioning that characteristic of the ground field F𝐹F is not 2.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 RB-operator

Given an algebra A𝐴A and scalar λ∈F𝜆𝐹\lambda\in F, where F𝐹F is a ground field, a linear operator R:A→A:𝑅→𝐴𝐴R\colon A\rightarrow A is called a Rota—Baxter operator (RB-operator, for short) on A𝐴A of the weight λ𝜆\lambda if the following identity

R​(x)​R​(y)=R​(R​(x)​y+x​R​(y)+λ​x​y)𝑅𝑥𝑅𝑦𝑅𝑅𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑅𝑦𝜆𝑥𝑦R(x)R(y)=R(R(x)y+xR(y)+\lambda xy) (1)

holds for any x,y∈A𝑥𝑦𝐴x,y\in A.

Let us list some examples of RB-operators of zero weight (see, e.g., [9]):

Example 1. Given an algebra A𝐴A of continuous functions on ℝℝ\mathbb{R}, an integration operator R​(f)​(x)=∫0xf​(t)​𝑑t𝑅𝑓𝑥superscriptsubscript0𝑥𝑓𝑡differential-d𝑡R(f)(x)=\int\limits_{0}^{x}f(t)\,dt is an RB-operator on A𝐴A of zero weight.

Example 2. A linear map R𝑅R on polynomial algebra F​[x]𝐹delimited-[]𝑥F[x] defined as R​(xn)=xn+1n+1𝑅superscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑥𝑛1𝑛1R(x^{n})=\frac{x^{n+1}}{n+1} is an RB-operator on F​[x]𝐹delimited-[]𝑥F[x] of zero weight.

Example 3. Given an invertible derivation d𝑑d on an algebra A𝐴A, d−1superscript𝑑1d^{-1} is an RB-operator on A𝐴A of zero weight.

Lemma 1. Let A𝐴A be an unital algebra, P𝑃P be an RB-operator on A𝐴A of zero weight.

a) 1∉Im​P1Im𝑃1\not\in\mathrm{Im}\,P;

b) if A𝐴A is simple finite-dimensional algebra and dimA>1dimension𝐴1\dim A>1, then dimker⁡P≥2dimensionkernel𝑃2\dim\ker P\geq 2;

c) if P​(1)∈F𝑃1𝐹P(1)\in F, then P​(1)=0𝑃10P(1)=0, P2=0superscript𝑃20P^{2}=0, and Im​P⊂ker⁡PIm𝑃kernel𝑃\mathrm{Im}\,P\subset\ker P;

Proof. a) Assume there exists x𝑥x such that P​(x)=1𝑃𝑥1P(x)=1. We have

1=1⋅1=P​(x)​P​(x)=P​(P​(x)​x+x​P​(x))=2​P​(x)=2⋅1,1⋅11𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑃𝑥𝑥𝑥𝑃𝑥2𝑃𝑥⋅211=1\cdot 1=P(x)P(x)=P(P(x)x+xP(x))=2P(x)=2\cdot 1,

a contradiction.

b) Let A𝐴A be simple, dimA=n<∞dimension𝐴𝑛\dim A=n<\infty. Suppose that dimIm​P=n−1dimensionIm𝑃𝑛1\dim\mathrm{Im}\,P=n-1. Given a nonzero x∈ker⁡P𝑥kernel𝑃x\in\ker P, we compute

0=P​(x)​P​(y)=P​(x​P​(y)),0=P​(y)​P​(x)=P​(P​(y)​x).formulae-sequence0𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑦𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑦0𝑃𝑦𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑃𝑦𝑥0=P(x)P(y)=P(xP(y)),\quad 0=P(y)P(x)=P(P(y)x).

Therefore, ker⁡Pkernel𝑃\ker P is closed under multiplication on Im​PIm𝑃\mathrm{Im}\,P. As A=Span​{1,Im​P}𝐴Span1Im𝑃A=\mathrm{Span}\{1,\mathrm{Im}\,P\}, we have a proper ideal ker⁡Pkernel𝑃\ker P in A𝐴A, this contradicts simplicity of A𝐴A.

c) From a), P​(1)=0𝑃10P(1)=0. All other follows from

0=P​(1)​P​(x)=P​(P​(1)​x+1⋅P​(x))=P​(P​(x)).0𝑃1𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑃1𝑥⋅1𝑃𝑥𝑃𝑃𝑥0=P(1)P(x)=P(P(1)x+1\cdot P(x))=P(P(x)).

Lemma 2. Let an algebra A𝐴A equal B⊕Cdirect-sum𝐵𝐶B\oplus C (as vector spaces), where B𝐵B is a subalgebra of A𝐴A with an RB-operator P𝑃P of zero weight, B​C,C​B⊆ker⁡P⊕C𝐵𝐶𝐶𝐵direct-sumkernel𝑃𝐶BC,CB\subseteq\ker P\oplus C. Then the linear operator R𝑅R on A𝐴A defined as R​(b+c)=P​(b)𝑅𝑏𝑐𝑃𝑏R(b+c)=P(b), b∈B𝑏𝐵b\in B, c∈C𝑐𝐶c\in C, is an RB-operator of weight 0.

Proof. Straightforward.

2.2 Chevalley—Warning theorem

For our purposes, let us write down the following version of Chevalley—Warning theorem:

Chevalley—Warning theorem. Let F𝐹F be a finite field and fi∈F​[x1,…,xn]subscript𝑓𝑖𝐹subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛f_{i}\in F[x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}], i=1,…,r𝑖1…𝑟i=1,\ldots,r, be homogeneous polynomials of degree disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} respectively. If d1+…+dr<nsubscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑟𝑛d_{1}+\ldots+d_{r}<n, then there is a nonzero solution to f1​(x)=…=fr​(x)=0subscript𝑓1𝑥…subscript𝑓𝑟𝑥0f_{1}(x)=\ldots=f_{r}(x)=0.

We also need the following result

Proposition [6]. Let F𝐹F be a field of characteristic different from 2 in which each quadratic form in three variables has a nontrivial solution. Then, for any a,b,c∈F∗𝑎𝑏𝑐superscript𝐹a,b,c\in F^{*}, there exist x,y∈F𝑥𝑦𝐹x,y\in F such that a​x2+b​y2=c𝑎superscript𝑥2𝑏superscript𝑦2𝑐ax^{2}+by^{2}=c.

For a finite field, Proposition could be derived from [10] as a corollary of Chevalley—Warning theorem.

2.3 Simple Jordan algebra of Clifford type

Let us introduce simple (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)-dimensional Jordan algebra Jn+1​(f)=F⋅1⊕Vsubscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓direct-sum⋅𝐹1𝑉J_{n+1}(f)=F\cdot 1\oplus V of a nondegenerate bilinear symmetric form f𝑓f acting on n𝑛n-dimensional vector space V𝑉V, n≥2𝑛2n\geq 2. The product on Jn+1​(f)subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓J_{n+1}(f) is the following:

(α⋅1+v)​(β⋅1+u)=(α​β+f​(v,u))⋅1+(α​u+β​v).⋅𝛼1𝑣⋅𝛽1𝑢⋅𝛼𝛽𝑓𝑣𝑢1𝛼𝑢𝛽𝑣(\alpha\cdot 1+v)(\beta\cdot 1+u)=(\alpha\beta+f(v,u))\cdot 1+(\alpha u+\beta v).

Let us choice such base e1subscript𝑒1e_{1}, e2subscript𝑒2e_{2}, …, ensubscript𝑒𝑛e_{n} of V𝑉V that the matrix of the form f𝑓f in this base is diagonal with elements d1,d2,…,dnsubscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2…subscript𝑑𝑛d_{1},d_{2},\ldots,d_{n} on the main diagonal. As f𝑓f is nondegenerate, di≠0subscript𝑑𝑖0d_{i}\neq 0 for each i𝑖i. Let us identify the form f𝑓f with the elements disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i}: f=(d1,…,dn)𝑓subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑛f=(d_{1},\ldots,d_{n}). By (v,u)𝑣𝑢(v,u) for v=∑i=1nvi​ei𝑣superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖v=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}v_{i}e_{i}, u=∑i=1nui​ei𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑒𝑖u=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}u_{i}e_{i}, we denote the sum ∑i=1ndi​vi​uisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}d_{i}v_{i}u_{i}.

It is well-known [18] that Jn+1​(f)subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓J_{n+1}(f) is a quadratic algebra, it means that any element x∈Jn+1​(f)𝑥subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓x\in J_{n+1}(f) satisfies a quadratic equation x2−t​(x)​x+n​(x)​1=0superscript𝑥2𝑡𝑥𝑥𝑛𝑥10x^{2}-t(x)x+n(x)1=0 for some t​(x),n​(x)∈F𝑡𝑥𝑛𝑥𝐹t(x),n(x)\in F.

3 Bound theorem and 3-dimensional case

In light of Theorem 1, define nilpotency index rb​(Jn+1​(f))rbsubscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓\textrm{rb}(J_{n+1}(f)) as a minimal natural number s𝑠s such that any RB-operator of zero weight on Jn+1​(f)subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓J_{n+1}(f) is inlpotent in the power s𝑠s.

Statement. All RB-operators of zero weight on simple Jordan algebra J3​(f)subscript𝐽3𝑓J_{3}(f), f=(d1,d2)𝑓subscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2f=(d_{1},d_{2}), are the following

Corollary 1. Let F𝐹F be an algebraically closed or finite field, then rb​(J3)=2rbsubscript𝐽32\textrm{rb}(J_{3})=2.

Proof. The main question is to find a nonzero solution (a,b,c)𝑎𝑏𝑐(a,b,c) of the equation a2−d1​b2−d2​c2=0superscript𝑎2subscript𝑑1superscript𝑏2subscript𝑑2superscript𝑐20a^{2}-d_{1}b^{2}-d_{2}c^{2}=0. Over algebraically closed field it is enough to consider c=1𝑐1c=1, b=0𝑏0b=0 and a=±d2𝑎plus-or-minussubscript𝑑2a=\pm\sqrt{d_{2}}. For a finite field, we apply Chevalley—Warning theorem.

The condition k​b+l​c=0𝑘𝑏𝑙𝑐0kb+lc=0 could be easily satisfied. At least one of the numbers b,c𝑏𝑐b,c is nonzero. Suppose that b≠0𝑏0b\neq 0, choose any l≠0𝑙0l\neq 0 and put k=−l​c/b𝑘𝑙𝑐𝑏k=-lc/b.

Remark 1. The statement of Corollary 1 could be not true for other fields. For example, in the case F=ℝ𝐹ℝF=\mathbb{R} and f=(1,1)𝑓11f=(1,1), we have rb​(J3​(f))=1rbsubscript𝐽3𝑓1\textrm{rb}(J_{3}(f))=1.

4 General case

Lemma 3. Let Jn+1​(f)subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓J_{n+1}(f) be (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)-dimensional simple Jordan algebra of the form f=(d1,…,dn)𝑓subscript𝑑1…subscript𝑑𝑛f=(d_{1},\ldots,d_{n}). Corollary 2. Let F𝐹F be an algebraically closed field and Jn+1​(f)subscript𝐽𝑛1𝑓J_{n+1}(f) be a simple Jordan algebra of a bilinear form f𝑓f over F𝐹F. We have rb​(Jk​(f))={2,k=3,3,k≥4.rbsubscript𝐽𝑘𝑓cases2𝑘33𝑘4\textrm{rb}(J_{k}(f))=\begin{cases}2,&k=3,\\ 3,&k\geq 4.\end{cases}

Example 6. Let F=ℤ7𝐹subscriptℤ7F=\mathbb{Z}_{7}, J4​(f)subscript𝐽4𝑓J_{4}(f) be a 444-dimensional simple Jordan algebra of the form f=(−1,−1,−1)𝑓111f=(-1,-1,-1). The following RB-operator R𝑅R on J4​(f)subscript𝐽4𝑓J_{4}(f) is defined by Example 5:

For investigating rb​(Jk​(f))rbsubscript𝐽𝑘𝑓\textrm{rb}(J_{k}(f)) over the field ℚℚ\mathbb{Q}, Hasse—Minkowski theorem could be used. It says that a quadratic form S𝑆S has a rational nonzero solution if and only S𝑆S has a nonzero solution over the real numbers and the p𝑝p-adic numbers for every prime p𝑝p.
